Le Serf, 1900-1903

NOT ON VIEW

Looking at Le Serf, it is tempting to imagine Matisse visiting the Rodin exhibition at the 1900 Paris World’s Fair as it brings to mind sculptures like L’Homme qui marche sur colonne (1877)? According to the art historian Alfred Barr, Matisse started working on Le Serf – which was at the time entitled L’Esclave – before the fair opened, during the winter of 1900. Pignatelli – a model of strong build who posed for many students of the Ecole des Beaux-Arts including Rodin and then Matisse – has often been confused with the Italian Bevilaqua, a man of rough appearance whom Matisse used as a model in his own studio.

Matisse is said to have worked on Le Serf during more than fifty sessions. He sketched and painted Bevilaqua for at least three years. The rough aspect of the sculpture – its surface imprinted with the marks of Matisse’s fingers – has been preserved on purpose. The forehead and clavicles, hollowed in places, emphasise the expression of a contented and defeated violence. A plaster version of the work was presented in 1904 at the Salon d’Automne. The arms, truncated in 1908 at the latest – when Le Serf was made into a cast iron sculpture – play a part in symbolically representing the despondency of the slave, his helplessness and his resignation, but also a kind of muted resistance.

There is a clear experimental aspect to this sculpture, and it is unique in Matisse’s work because of its medium but also of its allegorical title. It is the only male nude in his sculptural work.

Dos II, Issy les Moulineaux, 1913

Dos III, Issy-les-Moulineaux, 1916-1917

ON VIEW

ON VIEW

Matisse made 72 sculptures, 54 of which are kept at the Matisse Museum. Most of them are of average size, except for the monumental Dos [backs in English]. Dos II (1913) and III (1916-1917) are on view at the museum. Dos II and III are part of a series of four bas-reliefs representing a naked woman from the back and executed between 1909 and 1930. They exemplify the process through which Matisse simplified forms. Dos I describes in a realistic manner the shapes of a naked female body. Dos II highlights its construction through two symmetrical lines drawn along the vertical groove of the spine. Dos III emphasises the verticality of the work through the dynamic fusion of the legs, torso, hair and spine. In Dos IV, the body is reduced to the regular repetition of three vertical masses. The four Dos have been designed one after the other over a period of 22 years in a process which makes them simultaneously interdependent and autonomous. They were never cast in bronze nor shown together during the artist’s lifetime. They were displayed for the first time in 1956 at the Musée national d’art moderne in Paris.

Tempête à Nice, 1919-1920

ON VIEW

It is in 1917 that Matisse, a man from the North, first discovered Nice where he hoped to treat his bronchitis. From then on, he came back every winter and stayed in hotels until 1921. He then moved to place Charles Félix on the Cours Saleya.

The painting Tempête à Nice (Storm in Nice) was painted from the window of the Hôtel de la Méditerranée where the painter moved in November 1918. It evokes his first stay ruined by constant rain at the Hôtel Beau-Rivage in Nice. Disappointed by the poor weather, he was even ready to leave at some point as shown by a self-portrait (Musée Matisse, Cateau-Cambrésis) where he can be seen sitting in front of his easel in his hotel room, with an umbrella behind him and a suitcase at his feet: ‘I left l’Estaque because of the wind, and because I had caught bronchitis. I came to Nice to treat it, but it rained for a whole month. Eventually I made the decision to leave the city. The following day, the Mistral wind blew the clouds away, the weather was splendid’. Discovering the luminosity of the sea and the sky was a life-changing revelation : ‘When I understood that every morning, I would be able to see such light again, I couldn’t believe how happy I was’.

Tempête à Nice is one of the rare atmospheric paintings made by the artist, as his work, like Cézanne’s, tends to depict the permanence of things.

Odalisque au coffret rouge, 1927

ON VIEW

The Odalisque au coffret rouge (Odalisque with the Red Box) painted by Henri Matisse in 1927, is part of a series of paintings created in Nice in the 1920s. This series demonstrates the influence his travels to Algeria (1906), then to Morocco (1912, 1913), may have had on his work and his tireless research into the relationship between the volume of the body and the flat surfaces of the decor. Permanently installed in Nice since the beginning of the 1920s in an apartment overlooking Cours Saleya, Place Charles Félix, Matisse used it as the setting for exotic productions, in which he combined and juxtaposed fabric panels, screens, mattresses and rugs from his vast collection by interchanging them in a game of infinite variations.

The model’s pose, her more or less revealed nudity and the way she stands out, sculptural, against the background or, on the contrary, is integrated into it to the point of becoming a decorative element fully form part of these artistic variations. They show that if the orientalist imagination and feminine sensuality that it supposes permeate Matisse’s vision, they interest him less as a subject than as a pretext for systematic work on the nude and for renewing the link between background and shape.

In the Odalisque with the red box, an example of this intimate painting where only the colours generate light, the organisation of the space divided into horizontal registers is complicated by the opposition between the stripes of the wall and the languid pose of the figure. Its cast shadow, its curves and the few objects placed in front of the green mattress are the only elements to contradict a generalised decorative flattening. This confirms the artificiality of this type of exotic composition where the light skin of the model, Henriette Darricarrère, with whom Matisse worked between 1921 and 1927, shows how much his odalisques embody a fabricated Orient. His Moroccan paintings from the 1910s, marked by radical abstraction and the importance Islamic art had in his decorative conception of space, nevertheless remind us that he was undoubtedly the last great artist in Europe to think of the Orient as a reservoir of shapes and operator of artistic reflection.

Lectrice à la table jaune, Vence, 1944

ON VIEW

Confronted with the threat of German occupation, Matisse left Nice in 1943 and moved in the villa Le Rêve in Vence where he stayed until 1949. Painted during the spring of 1944, Lectrice à la table jaune is one of the numerous paintings from Matisse’s ‘Vence Period’. Here, Matisse returned to one of his favourite themes, that of women reading. The painting combines drawing and colour : on two expanses of colour, one blue and one yellow, just a few lines are needed to create the face and upper body of his model and assistant Annelies Nelck. She looks at a book lying open on a table along with a bunch of flowers, pomegranates and a Rhenish wineglass.

Fauteuil rocaille, 1946

ON VIEW

In 1942, Matisse bought a Venetian Baroque set (two armchairs and a pedestal table) from an antique dealer in Nice. On 20 April 1942, he wrote to the poet Aragon: “I have finally found the object I have wanted for the past year. It is a Venetian baroque chair in varnish-tinted silver. Like enamel. You have probably encountered something like it. When I saw it in an antique store a few weeks ago, I was completely taken aback. It’s splendid, I’m obsessed with it.”

The item that fascinated him so much appeared from 1942 in several interior paintings of the Régina, but it was in 1946 that Matisse undertook to represent it in the style of a portrait, as he had already done for La Table de marbre rose (The Rose Marble Table, 1917, MoMA, New York). The overhanging view, the tight framing, the conch shell open towards the viewer, the arabesque position of the armrests in the shape of dolphins, evoke the voluptuous pose of the seated models. This woman-armchair, half-plant, half-animal, reminds us of the artist’s taste for hybridisations which appear in many of his works, such as, for example, in the sculpture Jeannette V, whose head resembles a flower bulb.

Nature morte aux grenades, Vence, 1947

ON VIEW

Nature morte aux grenades (Still life with Pomegranates) is one of the masterpieces of the collection. It is deeply linked with Matisse’s presence in Nice and with the museum’s history as it was part of the first donation he made to the City of Nice in 1953. In 1949, Matisse designed a poster for the tourist office, using this painting to which he added the words “Nice, Travail & Joie” written in his own hand (Nice, Work & Joy).

Nature morte aux grenades belongs to a series of paintings entitled “Intérieurs de Vence” (Vence interiors). This is the last significant set of paintings made by Matisse. Painted in Vence between 1946 and 1948, they can be considered as his farewell to painting as he would later devote most of his time to the creation of the chapelle de Vence. Three of these paintings revolve around the pomegranate theme – Nature morte aux grenades fond rouge (private collection), Nature morte aux grenades (Musée Matisse Nice), and Intérieur rouge, nature morte sur table bleue (Kunstsammlung Nordrhein-Westfalen, Düsseldorf).

Painted between late October 1947 and February, all these compositions have elements in common : a plate with pomegranates placed in front of a window opening onto a flamboyant Vence palm-tree. Experimenting with this simple arrangement, the painter varies hues and patterns. Boundaries are blurred between inside and outside while the window frame duplicates the frame of the painting. Objects are outlined in the same way as Camille Joblaud’s profile in the medallion portrait that stands out against the black expanse on the right of the composition.

Danseuse créole, 1950

ON VIEW

In 1950, Matisse created Danseuse créole (Creole dancer), a new interpretation of the theme of dance.

According to Aragon, the painter was inspired by the Afro-American dancer and choreographer Katherine Dunham. Matisse’s work is also deeply rooted in the exotic, which the poet and traveler John-Antoine Nau calls “a waiting paradise” and which is directly related to the Baudelairean inspiration guiding his work since Luxe, calme et volupté (1904, Orsay Museum, Paris). In order to illustrate a book in honour of his poet friend – created in the workshop of the printer and lithographer Fernand Mourlot

From 1945 onwards Matisse, whilst in Paris, starts to draw models from Martinique and Madagascar. At the convergence of these two movements, Danseuse créole is characterized by the vivacity of its interpretation and the movement of the shapes contrasting with the background made of geometric areas. The dancer launches diagonally into the composition. She is wearing a costume with an abundance of joyful curves reminiscent of the vision of an imaginary creature, half-bird, half-plant. It illustrates Matisse’s fondness for artistic performances and music, in particular jazz, as well as his knowledge of Afro-American culture, discovered during his travels to New-York from 1930 to 1933. Danseuse créole, by its exuberance, contrasts with the sacred character of Zulma (1949, Statens Museum for Kunst, Copenhagen), and the dislocated character of La Négresse (1952-1953, National Gallery of Art, Washington). The painting conveys enjoyment of life, just like fireworks.

Vitrail, étude pour l’Arbre de vie, 1950

NOT ON VIEW

The Matisse Museum houses two studies for the stained-glass window L’Arbre de Vie (The Tree of Life) of the Chapel of the Dominican Sisters of the Rosary in Vence. For Matisse, the chapel is like a book of which some pages are in colour, i.e. stained-glass windows and others are in black and white, i.e. the ceramic panels of Saint Dominic, the Virgin with Child and Way of the Cross. Before finally creating L’Arbre de Vie, Matisse worked successively on two compositions of paper cut-outs: first Jérusalem céleste, made out of geometric shapes, primarily red (1948, Musée National d’art Moderne, Centre Georges Pompidou, Paris), then Vitrail bleu pâle (1949, Musée National d’art Moderne, Centre Georges Pompidou, Paris) composed of geometric areas, in which emerge shapes of plants – memories of a trip to Tahiti in 1931. However, Matisse, not having taken into account the technical difficulties of assembling the stained-glass window, creates a new composition. In this new creation, the palette, ranging from blue cactus to yellow flowers, symbolizes life that is resistant to drought and death. The clear ultramarine and bottle-green glasses allow us to see the landscape; the opaque lemon yellow is reminiscent of the dazzling light. Matisse owes his success to his collaboration with the master glassmaker Paul Bony and the glass factory of Saint-Just-sur-Loire – still in operation today – which created specifically for him the frosted yellow. The combination of primary colours creates unexpectedly – depending on the hour of the day – a magenta reflection that is diffused in the white atmosphere of the Chapel.

Nu bleu IV, 1952

NOT ON VIEW

Nu Bleu IV created in 1952 in the workshop of the Régina, is part of a set of four compositions created with cut-outs, the Nus Bleus series. Compared to the other three, Nu Bleu IV is produced over a long time – whereas all the other paintings in the Nus Bleus collection are produced with one single snip of scissors. It is recognized as the template for the others, with pencil strokes and adjustments to the blue paper cut-outs still visible.

If Matisse didn’t prefer a particular colour on his palette, blue became a privileged colour in his work. During the last few years of his life, he uses a type of blue with a particular texture so as to obtain a luminous medium through the use of flat-tints. The intense blue of the cut-out is not meant to symbolise the colour of the sea, but simply because Matisse, through long experimental researches, recognised that this particular blue had a fixing capacity to generate gradually light and colour. The intensity of this unique blue challenges the spectator, similar to the strike of a gong that stops all action, and attracts attention carrying it towards a new vision and a new balance.

In Nu Bleu IV, empty spaces which dissociate the blue parts, enhance the pose of the model. With this discontinuity in the representation of the limbs, he creates a new harmony in which the white of the sheet of paper contributes to the unity of the pose.

La Vague, 1952

NOT ON VIEW

La Vague (The Wave) created in 1952 with cut-out painted with gouache uses empty and filled spaces to conjure up movement.

Out of a rectangular paper painted with blue gouache, Matisse cuts a sinusoid, in one go, using scissors, – creating two blue pieces that he arranges on an empty white backing. By shifting them, he creates an empty space which, when either widened or narrowed, gives the impression of a ripple reminding us of the movement of the swell of the ocean.

During the 50s, Matisse frequently uses paper cut-out painted with blue gouache – a feature of the works of this period – which, thanks to its contrast with the white paper, allows to simplify and bring out the shapes.

This remarkable work – by the visual impact it induces – gives an impression of movement, creating a relation between its static part, the blue colour, and its more dynamic part, the white colour. Thanks to a single line splitting in two and the expansion of the shapes, a life-like impression emerges from the painting.

Fleurs et fruits, 1952-1953

ON VIEW

This cut-outs composition created in 1952-1953, is remarkable because of its size, more than 8 metres long and 4 metres high. It is the largest cut-outs work kept in French collections, an exceptional testimony of what is considered the apotheosis of Henri Matisse’s work.

This piece is part of a set of studies conducted by Matisse in connection with the order of a panel of ceramic tiles for the patio in the villa of Ms and Mr Sidney Brody in Los Angeles. Just like La Grande Décoration aux masques (National Art Gallery, Washington), Fleurs et fruits is the first idea of a project that will not see the light of day as Matisse chooses another pattern, called La Gerbe (LACMA, Los Angeles).

In the same way as colours are displayed on a palette, Matisse uses shapes cut out of paper covered in gouache of vibrant colours, which he places and moves around – according to his inspiration – on the walls of his apartment-cum-workshop at the Regina in Nice. The general composition of Fleurs et fruits is symmetrical with two fluted columns supporting a capital, placed at both ends of the work, giving an architectural aspect to the creation. Fleurs et fruits created by Matisse two years prior his death, gives his art a touch of eternity, as described by the poet Aragon in Henri Matisse, roman: “ As if I were going to compose on a large scale (…). As if I had my whole life ahead of me, or rather another life (…) in some paradise where I would make frescoes…”.
